Angela Merkel is to stand down as leader of the Christian Democratic Union, a post she has held for 18 years, after a dismal performance by the party in elections in the central German state of Hesse on Sunday badly dented her authority.

German media said she told senior party leaders at a meeting on Monday morning that she would not stand as CDU leader at the party conference in Hamburg in December.

While many see the instability in Germany as negative for the chances of Eurozone reform and an adequate EU response to challenges such as the Italian government’s fiscal policies, Brexit and US trade wars, we highlight the rise of the pro-EU Greens as a significant potential positive, at least for the Eurozone. It is even no longer impossible to see the Greens challenging for first place at the national level and thus the German Chancellorship. Thus, the decline of the old order could give rise to Germany’s Macron moment, as in France 2017, where a reinvigorated centrist movement drives the reform agenda at the national and the European level.

BE11:19am

Red Hat provides open source cloud software to enterprises. The company generated $2.8bn of revenue in CY17 and $757mn of EBITDA in CY17. Following the transaction, Red Hat would operate as a distinct unit within IBM’s hybrid cloud business. IBM expects the transaction to accelerate revenue growth, gross margin, and free cash flow within the first twelve months.
At the strategic level, the acquisition of Red Hat is consistent with IBM’s stated goal of expanding its reach across various elements of hybrid cloud infrastructure, where it already has a significant footprint in middleware, operating systems, and cloud services. With $2.9bn in annual sales (CY17), Red Hat would represent about 12% of IBM’s reported total software sales. IBM’s overall software portfolio declined in sales by about 4% yoy in 3Q18 (equating to an annualized decline of ~$0.95bn); this compares to Red Hat’s CY17 software sales of $2.9bn.

There is, in all honesty, not a lot more to say here beyond the figures. Here's Morgan Stanley to outline the figures.

BE11:27am

HSBC reported 3Q18 adj PBT of US$6.2bn, 3% ahead of MS and 8% ahead of consensus. The question going into 3Q18 was around delivery of positive jaws in 2018, given high costs in 1H18. Adj. costs were 4% lower than estimates and the key driver of 9% PPoP beat vs consensus. The bank retained its guidance of positive jaws for 2018.
Revenues were 1% ahead of consensus and 2% shy of MS. This was driven by a US$304mn hit from a change in accounting for Argentina (IAS29). On the cost side, there was a benefit of US$139mn from this move. Adjusting for those items, NIM would have been in line with Cons, and the PPOP beat would be 12%.
Loan impairment charges picked up to ~20 bps from 9 bps in 2Q18. This was driven by some ECL charges in Mexico, UK, Asia and MENA. The bank also took an overlay on account of potential impact of trade tariffs. CET1 increased 10 bps QoQ to 14.3% and TNAV was flat qoq.

BE11:28am

And Goldman, repeating much of the above.

irish hedge fund guy Yes Oracle, i always like the fact the people who sold peoplesoft to Oracle for $10bn waited a few years and launch workday which is now worth $27bn

11:28 am
BE11:28am

HSBC 3Q18 underlying PBT of US$6,193mn was 7%/8% ahead of GS/company compiled consensus on higher revenues and lower expenses. PPOP was a c.11%/9% beat, largely on better NIMs esp. in HK/RBWM and as costs were lower mostly due to Argentina’s hyperinflation. Results were clean and stated revenues, PPOP, PBT and net income were 3%/1%, 8%/7%, 4%/6% and 5%/7% better than expectations. Excluding the effect of classifying Argentina as a hyperinflationary country (per accounting norms) underlying PPOP , PBT were 14%/12% and 10%/11% better. We raise 2018E/19E/20E GS EPS by 2.0%/2.6%/3.1% to reflect the beat. We maintain our Buy rating and raise our 12m RIM-based TP to HK$84 (from HK$82) on the back of higher earnings. We expect the stock to react positively to the event.

Peel Hunt goes from "buy" to "sell" on Uberoo.

BE11:34am

Eight reasons why we are now sellers:
1. Uber Eats will dominate the smartphone real estate;
2. Deliveroo’s bigger pockets will see it thrive;
3. Just Eat may not be able to address all of its new market;
4. Just Eat’s vendor discounts don’t mean others can’t thrive;
5. Data may be Just Eat’s biggest asset, but that won’t last long;
6. Grubhub repositioned in a different time, today it is thriving;
7. The age of the high margin platform model could be ending; and
8. For Just Eat, 3Q18 is likely to have been a tough period.

BE11:35am

The box at the top refers to "an Uberoo-esque wave that eventually sees the demise of Just Eat," which is rather more punchy than you see in most sellside.

BE11:39am

One of the benefits of being on the Just Eat platform is the vendor discounts that it is able to get for its restaurants using its huge buyer power. This has meant that the savviest of restaurants have been able to save almost enough to offset the entire commission that it pays away to Just Eat, thanks to discounts for its core ‘ingredients’ (c50% is the potential typical saving that could be achieved). This is still the case, and we believe a huge benefit for its customers.
However, we don’t believe that those discounts are exclusive: you just need to be a Just Eat partner to access them. This would therefore mean that those same restaurants could sign up to Uberoo to gain access to more traffic, and not lose the discounts from Just Eat. Moreover, the discounts could actually incentivise the restaurants to sign up with Uberoo as that will drive more volume and may allow them to see even greater discounts. Even if that wasn’t the case, it doesn’t seem that the vendor discounts are yet really having an impact on the restaurants themselves either. At the full results, only £3m had been saved by vendors, compared to the £458.4m commission revenue that Just Eat generated in 2017.

Our View: Victoria has announced a first half trading update indicating that the Group continues to see organic growth in excess of 3% as it targets market share gains. There has been some near term pressure on margins as a result of this strategy, however the Group plans to recover the margin investment in stages over the next twelve months. In addition to the trading update the Group has announced plans to offer a €450m euro-denominated bond. In light of this process the below commentary is of a factual nature as we are unable to comment further until the process completes.
 First Half Performance – Victoria’s trading update covering the 6 months ended 29th September shows Group H1
LFLs have continued to exceed 3% as it targets market share gains. There has been some near term pressure on margins as a result of this strategy, however the Group plans to recover the margin investment in stages over the next twelve months.
 Plan to issue €450m Bond – In addition to the trading update Victoria has announced that it intends to offer €450 million in aggregate principal amount of senior secured notes due 2023 (the "Notes"). The Notes will be the general,
senior obligations of the Company and will be guaranteed by certain of the Company's subsidiaries. Interest on the Notes will be payable semi-annually in arrear. The interest rate, offering price and other terms will be determined at the time of pricing of the offering, subject to market conditions. The Company intends to use the net proceeds from the issue and sale of the Notes to repay the Company's existing senior bank facility.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

The substantial premium that IBM is paying for RHT might on the surface seem to make it highly unlikely that a superior bid could occur. However, we believe there is a reasonable possibility that another suitor could emerge. We emphasize that we do not yet know what the break-up fee for the proposed transaction is. But if the break-up fee does not present a massive impediment, we believe there are other companies that could take a hard look at RHT as a strategic target. Most likely would be CSCO (Silverstein) and GOOGL (Blackledge), in our view, although ORCL (Wood) would be a possibility as well. CSCO continues to emphasize software and recurring revenue through both M&A and internal initiatives. GOOGL has to date had mixed results with GCP (Google Cloud Platform) and would benefit from RHT’s enterprise relationships and distribution. ORCL has a server OS offering (Oracle Linux) but it has never found much market acceptance, and the co. could gain from adding a growth asset at scale and having a stronger hybrid cloud presence in its own right. At any rate, we look forward to learning more about the transaction from today's call and through subsequent filings. Separately, our new $190 price target (was $153) reflects the takeout price and corresponds to ~30x CY19 FCF.

BE12:08pm

Regarding the likely sale of the telematics unit, management talked about
interest from industry and financial buyers. We still value this business at
about EUR1.0bn, leaving c. EUR350m in EV for the Automotive, Enterprise
and Consumer units at a share price of EUR6.6 (or less than 1.0x 2019E
EV/sales for Automotive/Enterprise if Consumer is conservatively valued
at zero). With the group ex telematics generating cash, the cash proceeds
from a sale could be returned to shareholders, with a capital reduction in
our view the most efficient way to do this. However, the more sceptical the
market gets about the future of the automotive unit, the more interesting
it gets for the management/founders, who still own 44% of the share
capital, to take the company private after the likely sale of Telematics.
